verses.text: After many days, the word of the LORD came to Elijah in the third year, saying, 'Go, show yourself to Ahab, and I will send rain upon the earth.'
verses.comment: The reference to the third year aligns with the famine mentioned earlier in chapter 17.

verses.text: So Elijah went to show himself to Ahab. Now the famine was severe in Samaria.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the severity of the drought as context for Elijah’s confrontation.

verses.text: Ahab called Obadiah, who was over the household. Now Obadiah feared the LORD greatly.
verses.comment: Obadiah’s role is clarified, and his piety is emphasized.

verses.text: For when Jezebel destroyed the prophets of the LORD, Obadiah took one hundred prophets and hid them by fifties in caves, and provided them with bread and water.
verses.comment: Retains clear sequence and highlights Obadiah’s actions during Jezebel’s persecution.

verses.text: Ahab said to Obadiah, 'Go through the land to all the springs of water and to all the valleys. Perhaps we may find grass to keep the horses and mules alive and not lose all the animals.'
verses.comment: Maintains Ahab’s concern for his animals during the famine.

verses.text: So they divided the land between themselves to pass through it. Ahab went one way by himself, and Obadiah went another way by himself.
verses.comment: Stresses that both men searched separately, emphasizing the seriousness of the situation.

verses.text: As Obadiah was on his way, Elijah met him. Obadiah recognized him, and fell on his face and said, 'Is it you, my lord Elijah?'
verses.comment: Obadiah’s reverence for Elijah is maintained.

verses.text: He answered him, 'It is I. Go, tell your lord, "Elijah is here."'
verses.comment: Reflects the directness of Elijah’s instructions.

verses.text: And he said, 'How have I sinned, that you would give your servant into the hand of Ahab to kill me?'
verses.comment: Shows Obadiah’s concern for his own safety.

verses.text: 'As the LORD your God lives, there is no nation or kingdom where my lord has not sent to seek you. And when they said, "He is not here," he made that kingdom or nation swear that they could not find you.'
verses.comment: Underlines Ahab’s determined search for Elijah.

verses.text: 'And now you say, "Go, tell your lord, 'Elijah is here.'"'
verses.comment: Captures Obadiah’s nervousness about delivering the message.

verses.text: 'And as soon as I have gone from you, the Spirit of the LORD may carry you away to a place I do not know. So when I come and tell Ahab, and he cannot find you, he will kill me. Even though I your servant have feared the LORD from my youth.'
verses.comment: The possibility of supernatural movement is retained.

verses.text: 'Has it not been reported to my lord what I did when Jezebel killed the prophets of the LORD, how I hid a hundred men of the LORD’s prophets by fifties in caves and provided them with bread and water?'
verses.comment: Obadiah refers to his previous actions for credibility.

verses.text: 'And now you say, "Go, tell your lord, 'Elijah is here.'" He will kill me.'
verses.comment: Obadiah expresses continued concern for his life.

verses.text: Elijah said, 'As the LORD of hosts lives, before whom I stand, I will surely show myself to him today.'
verses.comment: The idiom 'before whom I stand' retained; statement emphasizes a solemn oath.

verses.text: So Obadiah went to meet Ahab and told him. And Ahab went to meet Elijah.
verses.comment: Summary of action, concise and faithful.

verses.text: When Ahab saw Elijah, Ahab said to him, 'Is it you, troublemaker of Israel?'
verses.comment: 'troubler of Israel' translated as 'troublemaker' for natural modern English.

verses.text: He answered, 'I have not troubled Israel, but you and your father’s house have, because you have abandoned the commandments of the LORD and followed the Baals.'
verses.comment: Direct accusation; 'followed the Baals' is an accurate rendering.

verses.text: 'Now therefore send and gather all Israel to me at Mount Carmel, and the four hundred fifty prophets of Baal and the four hundred prophets of Asherah, who eat at Jezebel’s table.'
verses.comment: 'Eat at Jezebel’s table' signals her personal support; verse retains original count of prophets.

verses.text: So Ahab sent to all the people of Israel and gathered the prophets together at Mount Carmel.
verses.comment: A straightforward narration of Ahab’s response.

verses.text: Elijah came near to all the people and said, 'How long will you hesitate between two opinions? If the LORD is God, follow him; but if Baal, then follow him.' But the people did not answer him a word.
verses.comment: 'Limp' or 'waver' rendered as 'hesitate'; question posed strongly in modern idiom.

verses.text: Then Elijah said to the people, 'I, even I only, am left a prophet of the LORD, but Baal’s prophets are four hundred and fifty men.'
verses.comment: Emphasizes Elijah’s isolation.

verses.text: 'Let two bulls be given to us, and let them choose one bull for themselves and cut it in pieces and lay it on the wood but put no fire to it. And I will prepare the other bull and lay it on the wood and put no fire to it.'
verses.comment: Instructions on sacrifice are kept direct and clear.

verses.text: 'Then you call on the name of your god, and I will call on the name of the LORD. The God who answers by fire, he is God.' And all the people answered, 'It is well spoken.'
verses.comment: Elijah’s challenge is stated plainly; people’s response is updated for natural modern English.

verses.text: Elijah said to the prophets of Baal, 'Choose one bull for yourselves and prepare it first, for you are many. Call on the name of your god, but put no fire to it.'
verses.comment: Elijah gives the prophets of Baal the first opportunity.

verses.text: So they took the bull given to them and prepared it, and called on the name of Baal from morning until noon, saying, 'O Baal, answer us!' But there was no voice, and no one answered. And they limped around the altar they had made.
verses.comment: 'Limped' retains the physical description of their ritual activity.

verses.text: At noon Elijah mocked them, saying, 'Cry aloud, for he is a god. Perhaps he is deep in thought or busy or traveling. Maybe he is sleeping and must be awakened.'
verses.comment: Retains Elijah’s sarcasm; 'busy' may mean 'relieving himself' per some translations.

verses.text: So they cried aloud and cut themselves as was their custom with swords and spears, until the blood gushed out on them.
verses.comment: 'Blood gushed out' is clarified for modern readers.

verses.text: Midday passed, and they continued raving until the time of the offering of the evening sacrifice, but there was no voice, no one answered, no one paid attention.
verses.comment: 'Raving' translates the Hebrew 'prophesying' or 'ecstatic'; phrase is rendered in readable English.

verses.text: Then Elijah said to all the people, 'Come near to me.' And all the people came near to him. And he repaired the altar of the LORD that had been destroyed.
verses.comment: Confirms Elijah’s focus on restoring the legitimate altar.

verses.text: Elijah took twelve stones, according to the number of the tribes of the sons of Jacob, to whom the word of the LORD had come, saying, 'Israel shall be your name.'
verses.comment: References renaming Jacob as 'Israel.'

verses.text: With the stones he built an altar in the name of the LORD. And he made a trench around the altar, large enough to hold two measures of seed.
verses.comment: 'Measures' is updated for modern readers; a 'measure' is about three gallons or thirteen liters.

verses.text: And he arranged the wood, cut the bull in pieces, and laid it on the wood. And he said, 'Fill four jars with water and pour it on the burnt offering and on the wood.'
verses.comment: Retains the details of preparation and saturation with water.

verses.text: He said, 'Do it a second time,' and they did it a second time. And he said, 'Do it a third time,' and they did it a third time.
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the miraculous nature of what is to come.

verses.text: The water ran around the altar and filled the trench also with water.
verses.comment: Clarifies the extent of saturation.

verses.text: At the time of the offering of the evening sacrifice, Elijah the prophet came near and said, 'O LORD, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, let it be known this day that you are God in Israel, and that I am your servant, and that I have done all these things at your word.'
verses.comment: Highlights the prayer and its purpose.

verses.text: 'Answer me, O LORD, answer me, so that this people may know that you, O LORD, are God, and that you have turned their hearts back.'
verses.comment: Prayer highlights God’s power in turning Israel’s heart.

verses.text: Then the fire of the LORD fell and consumed the burnt offering, the wood, the stones, and the dust, and licked up the water that was in the trench.
verses.comment: 'Consumed' expands to burning up everything, even water.

verses.text: When all the people saw it, they fell on their faces and said, 'The LORD, he is God! The LORD, he is God!'
verses.comment: Their response is direct praise.

verses.text: Elijah said to them, 'Seize the prophets of Baal; let not one of them escape.' They seized them, and Elijah brought them down to the brook Kishon and slaughtered them there.
verses.comment: Execution is rendered as 'slaughtered' for clear understanding.

verses.text: Elijah said to Ahab, 'Go up, eat and drink, for there is the sound of rushing rain.'
verses.comment: Promise of coming rain.

verses.text: So Ahab went up to eat and drink. And Elijah went up to the top of Mount Carmel. He bowed himself down on the ground and put his face between his knees.
verses.comment: Elijah’s prayer posture is clearly described.

verses.text: He said to his servant, 'Go up now, look toward the sea.' So he went up and looked and said, 'There is nothing.' And Elijah said, 'Go again,' seven times.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in prayer and repeated searching is highlighted.

verses.text: At the seventh time he said, 'Behold, a little cloud like a man’s hand is rising from the sea.' And Elijah said, 'Go up, say to Ahab, "Prepare your chariot and go down, lest the rain stop you."'
verses.comment: The cloud’s size and Elijah’s directions retained.

verses.text: In a little while the heavens grew dark with clouds and wind, and there was a great rain. Ahab rode and went to Jezreel.
verses.comment: Suggests urgency as storm arrives.

verses.text: And the hand of the LORD was on Elijah, and he gathered up his garment and ran before Ahab to the entrance of Jezreel.
verses.comment: Elijah’s supernatural speed is noted; 'girded up his garment' clarified.
